results.title: Stories of survival with Les Hiddins. [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Tim Clark, Richard Walker and David Telfer
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Bush tucker man series”.
Les Hiddins relates survival stories in four episodes. ‘The “Coffee Royal” affair’ set in Western Australia traces the story of Charles Kingsford Smith whose reputation was damaged by one of Australia’s earliest aviation disasters. ‘The Cannibal convict’ tells of one of the earliest convict escapees, Alexander Pierce in the wilds of south-west Tasmania. The footsteps of determined explorer John McDouall Stuart is retraced in ‘The Best of them all.’ ‘The Dutch settlement’ follows clues across Australia to investigate a report made last century about a Dutch colony established in Central Australia following a shipwreck.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ABC-TV (Australia), Tim Clark, Richard Walker and David Telfer

results.title: Stories of Rippon Lea Estate
results.brief_description:
Melbourne’s historic Rippon Lea Estate is one of the fabulous locations used in the popular ‘Miss Fisher’ television series. It has also been the venue for an exhibition of the costumes from the series.
Here, staff of the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), who manage the property, talk about its history, its use as a filming location, and the relationship between the producers of the series, the National Trust, and the enthusiastic audiences for the series who have also visited Rippon Lea and the exhibition.

results.title: Stories of Labassa
results.brief_description: The historic mansion ‘Labassa’ in Melbourne has seen many occupants and much activity in its more than 150 years of existence. Bronwyn Worrall, who manages the property for the community heritage organisation, the National Trust of Australia (Victoria), discusses the building’s history as a family residence, a home for ‘hippies’ in the 1970s and its use as a location for a number of films.

results.title: Stories in the Air
results.creator_credit: Video Books Productions and Gerben Cath
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Butler’s Video Books”.
A video designed to encourage children to read and enjoy books. Ten different stories, many from well known books, are told by professional storytellers and have been selected for children aged five to eight years old.

results.title: Stories in stone
results.creator_credit: East Coast Productions, Dennis Porter and Ian Austin
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hidden India Series”.
Mark Twain described India as, “the one land that all men desire to see and having seen once, even a glimpse, would not give that glimpse for all the shows of the rest of the globe combined”. This video explores many of the familiar and not so familiar monuments of hidden India. They range from massive carvings to mind-boggling man made temples.

results.title: Stories from Yambuk Youth
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Csilla Csongvay
results.brief_description: Five boys from Yambuk talk about what it means to be young in a small regional town and the various activities the town has to offer. They tell of the fun times growing up in the country, what they would like to change about the world and their ambitions for the future.

results.title: Stories from the earth
results.creator_credit: KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.) and Katie Jennings
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Fire on the rim”.
In days long gone, the lack of factual explanation for the eruptions, quakes and ancilliary disasters throughout the “ring of fire”, gave rise to myths and legends as means of coping with the impact of the erratic disturbances. Cultures both old and new have been partly shaped by such events, producing beliefs affecting the social behaviour of people living with the unpredictability of the earth. This program examines some of the fascinating stories that have emerged in these communitites.

results.title: Stories from a flying trunk
results.creator_credit: EMI/Parlophone, John Brabourne, Richard Goodwin and Christine Edzard
results.brief_description: Entertaining children’s film combining the use of live action, animation and ballet to present adaptations of three Hans Christian Andersen fairytales - The Kitchen, The Little match girl and Little Ida - where nanimate kitchen objects come alive, vegetables stage a ballet and magic fills the air. Featuring members of the Royal Ballet, including Lesley Collier (Princess Ida), Graham Fletcher and Denise Nunn with choreography by Frederick Ashton, music by Rossini arranged by John Dalby and conducted by Philip Gammon. Cast also includes Murray Melvin, Ann Firbank, John Tordoff, John Dalby, Patricia Napier, Tasneem Maqsood (the match girl), Johanna Sonnex (Ida).
